instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Clean board, at this point this is a project as it was left here abandoned and it will be nice to repair it.

Came in with a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C4205</CAPACITOR> 

I get 20V and 0.040A in USB meter

After removing short <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL> is still 0V so <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> has no output.

Is <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> the problem you think?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL>  comes from <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL>; do you get that one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The problem was way before that, <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> was shorted

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
That means no <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
No idea how/why did you go for <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> in such case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Came in with a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL> <CAPACITOR>C4205</CAPACITOR>, I was lost and needed some guidance, with your tip I was able to trace back the fault, thanks!
